header.title: Frugal's Take 096: Ageism and YouTube
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: A quick discussion about the very real ageism that exists on YouTube. Community Page https://www.facebook.com/YouTubeFruga... Social. Twitter    https://twitter.com/FrugalTech. LinkedIn   http://linkedin.com/in/brucenaylor. Amazon  Wish List  http://goo.gl/ns3NKT. FrugalBrothers http://frugalbrothers.com

commentThread.commentText:
Are you familiar with the sci-fi novel (or 70s-era movie) "Logan's Run?" I have no idea who the hell made this rule, but in IT, after age 22 your life-clock crystal starts blinking for Last Day. It's sad, but I've seen many comments by aspiring coders (and other IT disciplines) who say, "I'm 22 but feel bad because Linus Torvalds started programming at age 10, do you think it's too late for me to become a programmer?" LOL?

I enjoy seeing diversity in the IT sector of YouTube, regardless of age.

I just discover your videos today and been watching them all day long. I'll be 57yo in December and was always thinking about how 'different' I'm from other people my age. Playing and modding Fallout4 or Skyrim, listening to and watching Rammstein or Judas Priest, trying to produce some music on my DAW etc etc..... and I'm PC guy too - since DOS and Win3.1. So happy to finally get in 'touch' with a guy like you. Currently on disability due  to cancer, COPD and other 'crap', but feel the same way as you - inside I'm still in my 20's - ha ha. Thank you soooo much for what you doing !!!
I'm not quite old enough to experience blatant ageism yet, but it is a real thing, and it's unnecessary. I won't tolerate ageism, and neither should you.
I'd play on your BF4 server :P

Don't pay attention to modern stupidity of these days and on the twisted views of this wicked world.
Older people should receive respect and regard, not discrimination.
God bless you

We see the same kind of discrimination over here in South Africa too. Discovered your channel while searching for Xenyx desk setups. To be honest, I initially thought "What is this old guy going to teach me?"
Turns out you know more than I do, so now I'm subscribing to your channel.

replies.commentText: +ougibbons Thank you for subscribing!

commentThread.commentText: I learn allot from your videos, hope to watch more reviews
I really like your channel and how casually you talk about technology, so just keep going on :)  just ignore the trolls out there, I guess accepting the trolls is part of being a Youtuber!

replies.commentText: +Geekyranjit Thanks, and I will keep making these videos

commentThread.commentText: I'll be 61 next month - here's my take: complaining about discrimination is a losing effort.  Look at Blacks in America today.  Best to just accept it exists, and get on with your life.
What is your camera ?

replies.commentText: +nono007ification Recorded on a Sony AX53 camera.
+FrugalTech Thank's ! Do you like this camera ?

commentThread.commentText:
"to those who are Genuinely Interested" < I wish there were more people that were actually like that on YouTube. 

Also, you "admire and respect young people and how they embrace technology in their lives?" I don't know about being admired and respected for, say, going to an online school for some of my schoolwork.

It's interesting how you are right, because I don't think I've heard much about any amount (even 0.1%) of age discrimination for a while, and I think it's something I could improve on at least a bit. Thank you for making this video.

Hey Bruce. I am 65 years young. OK Sometimes I feel it in my body. I, however,  possess an analytical ability which I witnessed recently when helping my 13 year old solve a problem with a video program. I do observe that he normally catches on very quickly on how to use the program but my ability to solve and analyze is by no means diminished. In fact my analytical ability is strong. Apart from some body pain I don't think I am old, even using the word "old" strikes me as odd. So keep up the good work and keep spreading the good words and information.

Great Video Bruce. I am 70 . . . you are just a young pup. I think keeping up with tech has kept my mind younger and sharper than it would be otherwise. When you are young you think you know everything and as you age you realize that you didn't know anything afterall. It's always been that way...
awesome  video   age is  just   number   thank you
When I was in my twenties fifty seven was old. Now that I'm forty four? Not so much. When I was seven or eight, I thought people in their teens and twenties were old. It's all relative.

replies.commentText: +Julia Nelson Exactly

commentThread.commentText: The youngsters today have no idea what awaits them Bruce... Just like we did not have a clue! At 53 age, but 16 year mentality... I love how youngsters now look at me as though I have not got a clue... (ok that may be accurate...) yet.. have no idea what my background is, nor what amount of gear I have used and currently use now....  When the kids do see what I have it's like a major wake up call.... Have to agree with you on tech for ages though... there is certain tech that is aimed at a younger market... be it wearables... fashion etc.. yet... people in our age bracket... we seem to be getting left behind somewhat on the tech front... Tech Jackets... I want a pocket for wallet, glasses, keys, and THEN tech LOL!!! Anything on my wrist... if there is a way of looking at it without glasses... THEN its of interest! Ands thats the thing... until you get to a specific age and have to deal with the changes that come with it.. you really cannot appreciate... what is going to eventually come to us all!

+FrugalTech As I've gotten older (currently 38) I have been interested in how people solved problems well over 20 years ago. Hell, we sent people to the Moon in the 60s.

Keep up the great work I catch almost every one of your videos.
Hey, great video. I wholeheartedly agree; learning should never stop, regardless of age

replies.commentText: +Wadah Adlan Exactly

commentThread.commentText: The reason I started following you is your unique way of showcasing stuff, there's more patience that sometimes can't be seen with younger people. TBH you're not that old, I know people 20 years older than you that are coding with no problems. It's never about the age but it's about the spirit. As long as you got the spirit to show off interesting tech in a chilled and cool format like you do you'll always have my view.

For me, opinions of people who experienced more in the subject matter are much more relevant. I've seen a lot of tech channels with teenagers and for me it's kind of taking their opinions with a grain of salt.  they don't have much to compare it with.
You are telling so much truth. I am grateful  for your videos.  I call ageism bullying

replies.commentText: +gen murrai The real issue is that is is socially acceptable

commentThread.commentText: Hey man, you make awesome videos. That's all I care about. I hope I'm cool like that when I'm your age.

replies.commentText: +Cave Johnson I'm sure you will. The trick is to wake up everyday for years and years. :D

commentThread.commentText: I love your videos and I agree with you anyone any age can be on YouTube as long as they're not too young

Hey Bruce, I'm in the same ballpark related to age.  I agree that having and pursuing curiosity helps keep the mind young.  I still work as a database administrator and software developer and still love the technology.  I'm working on a Microsoft database certification to help with whatever age discrimination I run across in the job market.  Do technical certifications guarantee or prove anything?  No they don't, but it can't hurt.  I think part of age discrimination comes down to money.  Companies say they want fresh ideas from young people.  While that may be true in some cases, I believe that in most cases they can hire young people for less money and that's why they want to get rid of the older, better paid employees.  Thanks for the video.
Again age doesn't matter at all . If you have interesting things to say, than I'll be interested.
Your videos are sometimes more valuable to me, because You have other point of view. valuable
In Canada you can carry on working after 65, they can't make you retire just because if your age.

replies.commentText: no one makes you retire, businesses would rather have younger, middle age people work for them than old people.
@Satyam PatelÂ But if they fire you because you are old you can take them to an employment tribunal. It just like any other discrimination in Canada it is against the Law.
@Graham Linux yeah you are right. There are a lot of worker protection laws in place in Canada compared to America.

commentThread.commentText:
I subscribed after watching a few videos and seeing how you presented tech topics.  I did notice that I had never seen a tech channel w/ a host over 30-40, but that didn't mean the content was inferior.  It's the same stuff we're all interested in hearing about. I also think your engagement in the comment discussion is nice.
btw I'm 24 and think wearables are dumb too.

I am 28 in May and I always find that it doesn't matter how old you are, just how old you feel, and being older can have an advantage when it comes to having more experience and knowledge, which helps and one reason why I like your videos,  because of your knowledge and your passion to make tech videos like you do.I subscribe to a lot of YouTube channels from people that range from ages younger than I am or around my age in their late 20s to early 30s or even people in their 40s to your age like Michael Buckley or Tony Lee Glenn etc... and its not their age that I am concerned about and never will be, it is the content they produce and how good it is.

replies.commentText: +DynamixWarePro Thank you. It is or at least should be about the content!

commentThread.commentText: I'm 51 and oh do I know what you are talking about!

replies.commentText: +Matt Anderson Thanks for watching Matt

commentThread.commentText:
Very interesting topic Bruce.Â  Iâ€™ll offer my opinion regarding this, because
surely one opinion video welcomes the opinion of a viewer.Â  More and more â€œolderâ€ folk (by which I think officially classed anybody over 50 is classed as â€œoldâ€) are getting on the
Internet â€“ probably due to their jobs, and just because thatâ€™s the way the world is going.Â  Now people over the age of 70, things are very different â€“ older people around that age have probably used a computer, but itâ€™s been very limited, and the chances of them owning one in their house is probably as lot lower than somebody twenty years
younger.Â  I wouldnâ€™t say the Internet is just for younger people because when it was initially created, many of us didnâ€™t even exist (myself included), but certain sites; such as Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Twitch, and even a lot of gaming services such as Steam, I would imagine have a lot more younger users, probably a large majority of people under
the age of 40.Â  It reminds of another English guy over here on Twitch, I canâ€™t remember his exact name now, but at the time he was 67 and was streaming and playing Battlefield, and wasnâ€™t half bad either.Â  A lot of YouTuberâ€™s tend to be younger, and by that I suppose at the very most are under 40 â€“ Iâ€™m not saying all, but just most.Â  Does it bother me?Â  No, itâ€™s great to see more people online and enjoying themselves and expressing their creativity.Â  Does ageism itself exist?Â  Well, I would imagine so as YouTube itself is deemed something for the younger people.Â 
I myself also use YouTube instead of watching TV, whereas my parents watch TV in the evenings â€“ this also makes me wonder about the future of cable TV itself when online services such as Netflix are coming out, and you can watch what you want, when you want (without commercials?Â  I donâ€™t use Netflix).Â  I do think the Internet in regards to the future is going to be a lot more of a service and in our lives a lot more than cable TV ever was, and with services such as Skype will telephone services also cease to exist as  everything goes online? Certainly very interesting indeed.

Was the hat just â€˜because you had it sitting aroundâ€™?Â  ;)Â  As you said in your video, itâ€™s nice to see older people using technology, which I can see as being ageist, but at the same time I also think itâ€™s bad to see younger people using technology, and Iâ€™m talking about those tablet devices made for small children.Â  They should be outside having fun, scuffing their knees, eating mud and just doing what children do!

Talking about different ages and employment Iâ€™m going to talk about my father.Â  He works (or did, heâ€™s a manager now) in the haulage industry â€“ his company are having problems,
as is most of the haulage industry getting people my age into it...Older people are retiring, and not enough people are going into the industry to take up the slack.Â  I think the average age of drivers is 51.Â  As for my dadâ€™s company before they started offering an apprenticeship scheme I think the youngest person, at least in the UK side of the company was 34.Â  Most were aged between 45-55.

As for that â€˜too old to learn anything newâ€™, well to an extent, rather worryingly Iâ€™ve reached that point myself.Â  Donâ€™t get me wrong, I love technology, but certain aspects...VR, smart watches, Google Glass and other devices like that, I really donâ€™t want it forced down my throat. Maybe Iâ€™m just stubborn, but Iâ€™d rather have a computer for computing tasks, and then when Iâ€™m out to get away from it.Â  I own an iPhone, but itâ€™s only ever connected to WiFi when Iâ€™m at home...As soon as I go out all my social networking sites stop â€“ if people want me, they can call me. 

Iâ€™ve often thought of going the same way Dave Cullen at computingforever has and getting a non-smartphone, but at the same time Iâ€™d still like to use Snapchat and Instagram â€“ which is probably the primary use of my phone as it is.Â  A lot of people my age donâ€™t really do telephone calls anymore, or text...They might ask to FaceTime (similar to Skype â€“ you can see each otherâ€™s faces), but thatâ€™s about all.

I think that as long as you use technology to assist, and donâ€™t allow it to take over, then yes â€“ you can have a better life by incorporating it and using it to itâ€™s potential.Â  Great video Bruce, and youâ€™re not â€œtoo oldâ€ â€“keep at it, and keep having fun with it!  Happy Easter, and I hope that you and your family have a fantastic weekend.

replies.commentText: +SuperFIFTHGEAR Cable tv as we know it will probably shrink in viewership, to the point it may disappear. YouTube and other internet channels will replace it. The hat? Well it's just something new to my videos.Happy and safe Easter to you as well.

commentThread.commentText: Great video Bruce, a worthy discussion. I get that question a lot too â€¦ we are many years wise :D

commentThread.commentText:
Hey Bruce, that camera footage does look very very nice.  There should be a setting to lock exposure and white balance for when shooting indoors. I got my PJ440 and just set the exposure and white balance. Then just make a preset in FCP to key those in each time. 
Now young man lets talk about age.. LOL.. Your not old, yea your 18 years older then I but heck, I got grey hair popping out each day as well, plus this horrid bald spot on top. But dont let age ever get you down. Once you stop living life is when you will stop living life. Ya know I think my mental age stopped at 25, but I spent over 6 years in the military since age 21. So I guess I got a lot of good life lessons in a short amount of time to help me make better decisions now. But my love for things and how I see the world, life and people around me never moved past that. I am a little more out of shape these days. But if I was still in the same shape I was then, life at least in my eyes would keep moving on the same around me. I am often shocked when I see photos on Facebook of kids of my friends that are not kids anymore. Their in high school or even college. I am normally left wondering, damn, did I just sleep ten years away. Where did the time go.
What is sad though is the time it takes to foster a carrier these days. Heck lets look at this YouTube thing we both go going on or any real business for that matter. Takes 5 years to get it up to full speed. Then about another 5 more to set it in stone. Thats 10 years gone, 1/10th of our life expectancy. At least for 1/10th for those of us who don't smoke or drink like a fish. IDK, but then again if we wasn't doing something, that would be equally as bad. 
Anyway, I dont see you as old(er). I see you as Bruce. A wonderful person who has videos I enjoy and a person I hope to meet one day. So ignore the trolls, lord knows they been around since the days you and I were logging into BBS's on our old Hayes or Wang 1200bps modems. Often they are just the asshurt kids of democrats that just need a well placed mule kick in the face. So dont let their BS get to you. Make sure you drink your ensure and take care ;-)  Joe

replies.commentText: +Joe's Photo & Video Channel haha just finished my ensure :D Seriosly thank you. right now spending time with the camera and learning it's features.

commentThread.commentText: It's because there where less engineers in "digital" subjects like computers when you where in your 30's.

I'm 67 and watch your channel to learn new tech and what I can do with it. I have a friend who it my age. In fact we went to school together. He isn't interested in computers and has a hard time working his cell phone. For him it's easier to ask me to update his computer and phone. I'm still working and running a company and he's been retired since 60. Were both happy. I wonder sometimes who's doing the right thing. I just find it hard to stop, or as think of it give up.

replies.commentText: +Brian Binns It's great that you have a business, and are happy. Passion for life should never stop.

commentThread.commentText: Americans approach to aging has always baffled me but that may be because I was borne and raised in a different environment. Where I come from the older you are the more valuable your opinion. It's like a status symbol. Society treats you as a wise man that deserves the utmost respect. Now there are some that abuse that but it works for the most part. I am a younger man but I keep coming to this channel for reason. More 'entertaining' channels out there but probably not as balanced and thoughtful as this one.

replies.commentText: +Abdulai Bah Thank you. You're too kind!

commentThread.commentText: Bruce, you're doing just great.  Love the channel and awesome Honda motorcycle jacket!  57?  That's not old.  You are right, discrimination of all forms, needs to stop!  Please keep up the great work!

replies.commentText: +BrainDesmo Why thank you!

commentThread.commentText: 57? You young whipper-snapper! :-) I'm 64 and am as involved in tech and gadgetry as you are. I'm fortunate enough to work in an organization that actually values us codgers. I've been working in tech for 40 years and I'm as interested in and in love with it as I was when I first started. Great job, Bruce, and so glad you're out there sharing your knowledge and experience. Keep up the good work.

replies.commentText: +Donald Stidwell Thanks Donald, that means a lot!

commentThread.commentText: Hey Bruce - this 57 yr old just watched this video and went from a subscriber to fan!  Passion and enthusiasm will dictate your age with regards to virtually any aspect of life.  The improvements to technology have always been an enhancement to our lives and to not embrace them "at any age" would be naive at best.  Just for the record - my 94-year-old father and veteran of WWII - gets quite a kick out of his iPad which we gave to him last year!  He emails and can't quite get over the salaries of professional athletes that he has googled - you have got to love that!!

replies.commentText: +Steven Whitley Wow I bet you dad has kittens over the pro athlete salaries!  I sure miss my Dad. Thanks so much for you support

commentThread.commentText: If people make negative comments about your age, it means they've nothing better to exploit. I wouldn't even consider 50's that old, just older a lot of techies on YouTube. I think you're age is a massive advantage, because you've experience in both business and technology, and you've seen technology grow from its infancy, while our generation only gets to experience it in its current state. I'd say that on top of your personality makes you videos worthwhile for a lot of people.

commentThread.commentText: I think I prefer your tech videos. I like how you come across. You and Techmoan as part of YT's Mature Content Creators, I don't care that you're whatever age you are. commentThread.commentText: We oldies do have an advantage in the  jobmarket. In this day and age of part time work and lots of competition, employers favour older workers. It helps to stay curious and interested.

replies.commentText: +yellowlabrador Maybe. I keep hearing the opposite from some of my friends that have lost engineering an management jobs.

+FrugalTech The trick is to embrace minimalism. I found it sickening that all my money was going to others when I was working as an engineer. And on top of that unpaid (but obligatory) overtime. I downsized as soon as the kids where raised and I'm now better off with more money in my pocket. We are all sucked into taking on debt, keeping up with the joneses, paying bills, 'upgrading' and the big one, healthcare and a really big one, childcare. Older people are free to reject a lot of that if they are willing to look at their expenses and in my case, I am part self employed in tech and part time employed in a mundane non tech job and I'm coining it. NO to debt, credit cards etc and YES to quality of life . The only people with an iphone 6 I know, are 2 little girls under 10, who got them as presents, they have no sim in them but wave them about every time some one stops to talk to them. One of the fathers is declared bankrupt. I only buy new tech when it actually makes sense. I keep up with new stuff but I don't necessarily buy unless it's vital. I've still got a first gen moto g, off plan, so again cheap and it still has all the bells and whistles I need. The people who had it all, were our parents generation.
